Game module¶

class Game.Block(number: int, color: Game.BlockColors)¶

Bases: object

Block class that contains number and color of a block

Additionally contains some helper methods that will help simplify code later ahead

number¶

Contains the number for this block (practically a number from 0 to 6)

Type

int

color¶

Specifies what color this block is

Type

BlockColors

__init__(number: int, color: Game.BlockColors)¶

Prepares block data

Number and color will be treated as private data

Parameters

  • number (int) – This block’s number

  • color (BlockColors) – This block’s color

Raises

TypeError – If number is not int or color is not instance of BlockColors

color¶

Checks if this block’s color is the specified one

Parameters

color (BlockColors) – Color we want to compare this block’s to

Returns

True if this color and the passed color match

Return type

bool

class Game.BlockColors(value)¶

Bases: enum.Enum

Colors that are available in the game

Structuring the alternatives as an enum makes some aspects of the code more readable

Yellow = 3¶
class Game.Game(param=None)¶

Bases: object

Game class, which tries to implement a simple version of SixTowers

It does so by validating moves before performing them, and making sure to comply with all the basic game rules.

stacks¶

list of Stacks of Blocks with the current game arrangement

copy()¶

Make game copy and return it

Basically just clones stack attribute

Returns

Copy of current game

Return type

Game

is_valid_move(src: int, dest: int, src_height: int) → bool¶

Checks if move from src to dest with src_height is valid based on game rules

This function bascally establishes the game’s rules

Parameters

  • src (int) – Index of source stack in stacks array

  • dest (int) – Index of destination stack in stacks array

  • src_height (int) – Height of the source array to be moved

Returns

True if move complies with game rules

Return type

bool

Raises

ValueError – If inputs exceed stack size of height

move(src: int, dest: int, src_height: int) → bool¶

Perform a move action from origin to destination with specific height

Parameters

  • src (int) – Index of source stack in stacks array

  • dest (int) – Index of destination stack in stacks array

  • src_height (int) – Height of the source array to be moved

Returns

True if operation was successful

Return type

bool

parse_from_file(file_name: str)¶

Helper function to help fill the stacks attribute with the contents of a file

Parameters

file_name (str) – Name of the file from which the data will be extracted

Raises

ValueError – When file_name file is not found

possible_moves()¶

Python generator that returns all possible moves one by one

Returns

Source, destination indices and height of stack to be used with the ::meth::Game.Game.move() method

Return type

(src, dest, height)

print_stacks()¶

Print all stacks in a visually-appealing format

This format sort of ressembles the actual game

stacks¶
static_evaluation() → int¶

Evaluates game state and returns a number

The bigger the number of the game evaluation, the closer the game is to the winning state.

196 * 6 towers = 1176 corresponds to the winning game

Formula:
stack.height * sum(map(lambda x: x.number + 1, stack)) -

missing.height * sum(map(lambda x: x.number + 1, missing))

If stack is consecutive, missing.height = 0 and result will simply be the first term (sum of elements offset by 1 multiplied by its height)

If stack is valid, we need to extract the missing terms and

proceed with calculations. The subtraction will help penalize valid, but not consecutive stacks

Returns

Static evaluation of current game state

Return type

int

won() → bool¶

Checks if game fulfills winning condition

Returns

True if game fulfills winning condition

Return type

bool

class Game.Stack¶

Bases: object

Class that represents a stack of blocks in the game

Unlike the Stack Data Structure, it contains some unconventional operations and names that help make the main Game functions much shorter and simpler

head¶

Pointer to the top node of the stack

Type

Stack.Node

height¶

Amount of elements stored in stack

Type

int

isConsecutive() → bool¶

Checks if the stack of blocks is consecutive

Returns

True if the following blocks are the same color and follows the correct sequence after the previous one (1, 2, 3, etc.)

Return type

bool

isEmpty() → bool¶
isValid() → bool¶

Checks if the stack of blocks is valid

Returns

True if the following blocks are the same color and wider than the previous ones

Return type

bool

pop(n: Optional[int] = None)¶

Removes “n” amount of elements from top of stack and returns them as another stack (but in the correct order)

By default, it implements a more efficient solution, but when an integer n is added, it uses a more time-consuming alternative to extract and return all the popped elements in the correct order

Parameters

n (int) – Amount of elements to pop from top of stack

Returns

Removed elements

Return type

Block or Stack[Block]

Raises

ValueError – When popping more than the available height

push(element) → bool¶

Add block or other stack at the top of this stack

Parameters

element (any) – Can be a single Block or another Stack of Blocks

Returns

True if operation was successful

Return type

bool

Raises

TypeError – When trying to push elements that are not Stacks or Blocks

top(n: Optional[int] = None)¶

Extracts and returns “n” amount of elements from top of stack (in the correct order)

By default, it implements a more efficient solution, but when an integer n is added, it uses a more time-consuming alternative to extract and return all the popped elements in the correct order

Parameters

n (int) – Amount of elements to pop from top of stack

Returns

Top elements

Return type

Block or Stack[Block]

Raises

ValueError – When extracting more than the available height
